reviewText: Ok so I am one that has seen a lot of movies and let me say this! That this movie was very well put together. Spartacus staring Kirk Douglas is one of my most favorite movies that I have ever seen! So 3 days ago when I was just browsing you tube I watched a couple of the older films like the Colosseum etc. And finally the slave popped up as an option to watch. So being curious I looked into it further and read about it on the info section about the movie. And as soon as I saw it reference Spartacus son I just had to watch it.Now we all should know that it is unclear of whether or not Spartacus even had a son, he may have considering the fact he had a wife but total certainty is not clear. We also know that Spartacus was not crucified but actually killed during battle, and that he was probably a member of the Roman military before being made a slave pry do to desertion, however many a facts were in the film Spartacus, and believe it or not many a facts are still within this film too. Such as the manner in which Crassus is killed and the rebellion he was doing within Rome against Caesar. And so the way this piece is put together it is very believable that such a thing COULD have happened, pry didn't but is still possible.As the movie goes on though, one can't help but think of how similar this man acts to his father. Even though for a long time he does not even know that he is the Son of Spartacus and when he is first told it is hard for him to believe himself. But just the compassion he has towards slaves, his honesty, and his falling in love with a slave woman, it just brings back the thought  of......that's how Spartacus was. (But he is a friend to Caesar which is totally different.)The only thing I didn't like about the film is the stupid helmet he wears, I think something else could have been chosen instead of that big bulky thing haha which makes it a bit hard to hear him at times during fight scenes but then again just by watching him fight you get the idea of whats going on haha. Well sit back and enjoy the film and I recommend watching it on you tube and then buying it adding it to your collection. Oh on you tube type in English version of the slave though because the Spanish version comes up otherwise. Unless you speak Spanish then you are good to go.The ending however totally surprised me so be prepared to be surprised.

reviewText: THE SLAVE is one of the better and more serious Steve Reeves films, along with LAST DAYS OF POMPEII, MORGAN THE PIRATE, GIANT OF MARATHON, and DUEL OF THE TITANS.  By the time this film was made, Reeves had become better at reacting to his co-stars and was more comfortable performing for the camera.  The film was partially shot on location in Egypt, so the cinematography has a different visual look than most other Greco-Roman films.  Reeves plays a Roman centurion who discovers that he may be the son of the rebel slave Spartacus, leading to a Zorro-like nocturnal campaign of rebellion against the oppressive Roman establishment.Warner Archives has released a MOD DVD-R of this film in the original CinemaScope aspect ratio of 2:40-1.  This is a world home video premiere in the proper widescreen.  Foreign PAL DVDs of the film are all improperly matted to 1:66-1 or thereabouts.  These epic films always look better when properly letterboxed, due to their widescreen imagery.  Additionally, THE SLAVE was never released on VHS in the US, so this represents a stateside debut on home video.This welcome release of THE SLAVE leaves Reeves' THIEF OF BAGHDAD (1961) as his only film still unavailable in proper widescreen in any home video format in the world.  A recent Italian DVD of BAGHDAD is matted to 1:85-1.  I believe that MGM owns BAGHDAD via the Embassy Pictures library.
summary: world home video premiere in proper aspect ratio

reviewText: It is a real tragedy that so many of Steve Reeves films fell subject to neglect & were disregarded to the point that many are beyond repair. This movie is a exception, Warner Brothers have restored this film to its original widescreen ratio an beautiful vivid color! For fans of Spartacus this is a must have movie as it is about a Roman soldier who discovers he is actually the son of the famed Thracian rebel Spartacus! A Zorro type plot he keeps his true identity a secret by day but by night becomes a masked avenger freeing slaves. It is one of the better Steve Reeves movies ranking up there with "The Last Days of Pompeii" ,"Duel of the Titans" & of course his break out film "Hercules". "The Slave" is visually stunning & definitely worth seeing even if your not a fan of Mr. Reeves, it is still a great movie if your a fan of Sword & Sorcery or Sword & Sandal movies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If, like me, you are a great fan of "THE EPIC" movie, there's much to enjoy here!Steve Reeves at his handsomest best, ....although for some reason wearing a huge black Teddy-boy "quiff", when every other man is featuring a hairstyle that approximates the Roman fashion of the times.The producers must have spent most of the budget on sets, because there was obviously a very restricted limit placed on the amount of fabric to be used in each of the men's costumes. If you are a particular fan of well developed male upper thighs then you will be driven to complete ecstasy here as Mr. Reeves and Co. are all given the shortest possible little outfits to wear and decency is barely, ...and I do mean "barely" preserved! Quite spectacular in fact!Filmed partly in Egypt, using some long-suffering locals as the extras in the background, wearing their usual everyday dress, ....no fabric allowance for them at all!Still, you can't beat using the ACTUAL pyramids and the real Sphinx as your backdrops now can you?The budget seems to have gone almost entirely on a quite extensively built reproduction of the palace of Crassus.The movie itself has all the features you have come to expect from "THE EPIC"!There's the vaguely "ancient" music, ...from a very untuned horn section at times, .....the fine musculature development of most of the male cast, ...thankfully free from the steroid-induced, road-map vein laced excesses we see now!There's the wicked temptress with "designs" not entirely innocent upon the fine physique of our hero, ...and of course the long-suffering little servant girl/slave who we all know will triumph in the end."Wicked-woman" gets all the draped and filmy gowns reminiscent of the Italian fashions of the fifties than anything from the Roman Empire....poor slave girl gets the one frock that gets severly deteriorated as the plot advances, then a generic ordinary number that still manages to show off her two best "assets"....ahem!There's the obligatory dance routine we all wait for too, ...but this aspect is a bit disappointing in this particular film.They obviously just out-sourced every belly-dancer usually employed in the nightclubs and restaurants of Egypt to turn up in her usual performing drag and shimmy about individually. No budget needed for any matching costumes, ...nor synchronised choreography. Just attend casting call and writhe suggestively about the set.Pretty poor in fact, ...I do like those extravaganzas with all the girls leaping about in time while wearing the expected veils and beads.We do get the always enjoyable speeded up horse chases, ...the battle scenes and the marching armies. The sword fighting is actually fairly poor by epic standards,but not to the point of being hysterically inept as some epics can be.There's also the couple of "ingenious" means of putting to death any of the expendable characters.Most epics have at least one, ...but here there's four I think, ...apart from the usual beheading.Crucifixion of course, ...what would a Roman epic be without that?But there's a tank of piranha like inventions, .....in reality catfish when you see them.The victim is thrown in, the munching begins, the jacuzzi starts blowing bubbles, blood billows and a huge stone block then slides over the indoor aquarium to blot out the screams. Most thoughtful.There's also an outdoor pool that slowly floods to drown the victims tied to more crosses, and we are told a sluice gate opens for the rising tide to let in sharks or more of those piranhas, but although the gate does open we don't see any of the promised voracious sea-life.Then there's the centre-piece of the aforementioned dance routine.A large bee-hive shaped object is unveiled which seems to be some sort of a cane frame work all covered in some very anachronistic "saran" wrap, or cling-film.We notice that there are prisoners inside, and it starts to fill with some very pretty pink smoke.I was almost expecting Jeannie to appear, but no, we are told by Crassus it's the fumes from some noxious gas that can kill "without shedding blood".(Although why the sight of some flowing haemoglobin would be any worry to our evil Crassus is anyone's guess. He has the torture aquarium installed right in his throne room, ...and the drowning pool right under his window so he can enjoy the agonising screams at night as the tide come is!)The storyline is a simple one.Reeves is convinced by an old compatriot of the real Spartacus that he is indeed "Son Of Same", ...and this is confirmed by some matching amulets, one of which has been hanging around Reeves fetchingly tanned throat since birth.He than adopts a superhero role using a huge "Gort" like mask to hide his true identity as he appears to remain at court but also leads the slaves in attacks upon the faux (thankfully!)leopardskin clad guards of Crassus.Of course he's eventually caught, exposed and imprisoned.This is the EPIC genre, so no surprises there.Escape with help from that little slave girl who is so enamoured of his muscles, (and other parts too!) ....and well deserved retribution is taken on all the nasty villains, .,..including that Ms. Sexy Evil!Caesar is played by a quite convincing actor, ...although he is burdened with what looks like a huge surgically implanted sultana on the side of his neck. I was really starting to worry about a serious case of melanoma and wondering why anyone so inflicted would not have had such a monstrous great thing excised?Crassus chews the scenery with glee, ...and gets to wear sevearl voluminous costumes that seem to be free from the savage restrictions on fabric usage all other men have to abide by. (Perhaps he just had skinny legs?)His dispatch is of course historically totally apocryphal, ..but concurs with the legend that has come down to us as a punishment for his excessive greed for the accumulation of gold.All said this is far from the worst levels of bad movie making that the so called "sword-&-sandals" genre could descend to.Steve Reeves at his peak of physical perfection, ...dubbed voice of course, but certainly something to look at. The dubbing of ALL the characters is at times very obvious.Apparently Italian film makers never used live-sound on any shoots, even on interior sets.The reason is that they could never get the crew to shut up during takes!Hence each actor speaks whatever language during the shot, then all is dubbed in the sound studio later, and very often by other actors using English, ..or whatever language is required. Little effort is made to match the lip-movement seen on screen.Still all that being said, this is an enjoyable romp through those vaguely set "ancient times" and the quality of the transfer is fine for your large screen.Not quite as unintentionally "fun" as say Lana Turner in her nudie-dress in "The Prodigal Son", or Joan Collins in purple face makeup chomping on neo-Egyptoid surroundings in "Land of the Pharaohs". This is a bit more "serious", ...but only a tad.Popcorn required of course, ...and do close the history books as a prerequisite, but lovers of "THE EPIC" will recognise all the necessary elements represented here and that Mr. Reeves is probably the only bloke who can upstage the actual Sphinx itself!P.S. During the opening credits do look for the thanks given to the people of Egypt for their co-operation in the making of this film.The title adopted by the production company has to be read aloud to be believed!Surely a tongue-in-cheek (oops) intentional pun?They got away with it though!

reviewText: It is ironic that the two Italian Directors who would change the look of the Western genre in the mid sixties were cutting their teeth in the spectacle arena many years before.  Director Sergio Leone would direct the way ahead of its time epic 'THE COLOSSUS OF RHODES' aka 'IL COLOSSO DI RODI' -1961  and Director Sergio Corbucci would direct a series of spectacles with actor Steve Reeves of which this entry 'THE SLAVE-SON OF SPARTICUS' aka 'IL FIGLIO DI SPARTACUS'- 1962 emerges as Reeves peak as an action performer.  Almost a direct sequel to Director Stanley Kubrick's 'SPARTACUS' -1960, this film continues the legacy as Varinia's child with Spartacus matures and takes revenge on Crassus who was responsible for his fathers demise and crucifiction.  What we have is a magnificent film which sort of got lost in the shuffle with all of the Hercules, Samson, Maciste, Goliath etc. entries unleashed in abundance at that time.  The main characters are portrayed by brilliant familiar Italian actors. Besides Reeves performance of Randus, you have the over the top villainy of Claudio Gora as Crassus spewing so much saliva that the tapestries in his chambers seem drenched with it, the beautiful Gianna Maria Canale as Clodia who is Crassus's unfortunate playmate and incinerates the screen every time she appears, Jacques Sernas as the javelin throwing villain Vernas, and Ivo Garrani as Julius Caesar.  The only flaw is the lame acting of the Egyptian slave inamorata of Randus played by Ombretta Colli who's part could have been played by any Euro starlet at that time.  The film also shines behind the cameras as well with some of the best technicians fused together: Cameraman Enzo Barboni who would become a director of Spaghetti Westerns and photographed Director Corbucci's classic 'DJANGO'-1966 here shoots some of the most panoramic images of his career utilizing depth of field and Egyptian locations fused with some brilliant sets in the Titanus studios; the music score by Piero Piccioni is one of his best and the editing is by future Federico Fellini alumnus Ruggero Mastroianni.  Warner Archive releases the film in a DVD-R in its proper 2.35 ratio with great color and clarity in its English Dubbed Mono soundtrack and images. Director Corbucci would go on to direct the even better epic 'DUEL OF THE TITANS' aka 'ROMOLO E REMO' -1963 with Reeves and actor Gordon Scott utilizing some of the same technicians and help immortalize the Euro Western in a series of unforgettable films.  But for now, click the add to cart button and enjoy a film that must be seen in its widescreen format.  Along with Director Pietro Francisci's 'HERCULES UNCHAINED' aka 'ERCOLE E LA REGINA DI LIDIA'- 1960, 'THE SLAVE' emerges as one of the best of all Italian spectacles and Warner Archive deserves kudos for preserving it for future generations of action film lovers.
Title: N/A
